history.content: Whether it's ARM or MIPS, the idea remains the same. If you are worried, just watch previous years' lectures on MIPS to get a head start. But I wouldn't worry too much about it. Personally I find caches to be the hardest subject in 61c.

children.subject:
It's going to be ARM. Professor Katz said so in our final lecture of 61C this past semester.

Assembly isn't that difficult: it's just another language, another way of thinking about manipulating data. When they say computer programming is distilling a process to it's most basic steps in order to get a computer to perform them, assembly is just distilling it more. It's actually pretty easy once you understand registers. Don't let the strange-looking syntax get in your way, and more importantly, don't self-defeat from the beginning by telling yourself it's going be too difficult before you've even started for real.

The spring semester hasn't even started yet. I'm surprised to hear that you've gotten your other syllabi this early; I can't recall taking many courses that did so.

On the contrary, I can remember during the first lecture for 170 still finalizing the syllabus, and trying to figure out how to publish it on bCourses. (Answer: TAs can't publish courses, only professors can.)

So, just wait a few more weeks. As others have noted, it wouldn't change anything, even if the professor decides during the semester that he wants to switch back to MIPS for some reason.

history.content: Hi everyone. I'm hearing mixed comments between ARM being used this upcoming semester and retaining MIPS, including the recent post: @2858. It seems like it's going to take a long time for me to get even a bit comfortable with assembly language, so has anyone officially heard on what's going to be used? The syllabi for all my other classes have been released but we're still in the dark about 61C. I'd appreciate any advice/resources about how to get some practice and familiarity. Thanks!!
history.subject: CS61C Assembly Language that's going to be used
